Article.ArticleTitle: Acute Effects of Ambient Air Pollution on Asthma Emergency Department Visits in Ten U.S. States.

AbstractText: Previous studies of short-term ambient air pollution exposure and asthma morbidity in the United States have been limited to a small number of cities and/or pollutants and with limited consideration of effects across ages.

To estimate acute age group-specific effects of fine and coarse particulate matter (PM), major PM components, and gaseous pollutants on emergency department (ED) visits for asthma during 2005-2014 across the United States.

We acquired ED visit and air quality data in regions surrounding 53 speciation sites in 10 states. We used quasi-Poisson log-linear time-series models with unconstrained distributed exposure lags to estimate site-specific acute effects of air pollution on asthma ED visits overall and by age group (1-4, 5-17, 18-49, 50-64, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>65</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></math> y), controlling for meteorology, time trends, and influenza activity. We then used a Bayesian hierarchical model to estimate pooled associations from site-specific associations.

Our analysis included <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>3.19</mn><mtext> million</mtext></mrow></math> asthma ED visits. We observed positive associations for multiday cumulative exposure to all air pollutants examined [e.g., 8-d exposure to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>: rate ratio of 1.016 with 95% credible interval (CI) of (1.008, 1.025) per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>6.3</mn><mtext>-</mtext><msup><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> increase, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math>: 1.014 (95% CI: 1.007, 1.020) per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>9.6</mn><mtext>-</mtext><msup><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> increase, organic carbon: 1.016 (95% CI: 1.009, 1.024) per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>2.8</mn><mtext>-</mtext><msup><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> increase, and ozone: 1.008 (95% CI: 0.995, 1.022) per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>0.02</mn><mtext>-ppm</mtext></mrow></math> increase]. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and ozone showed stronger effects at shorter lags, whereas associations of traffic-related pollutants (e.g., elemental carbon and oxides of nitrogen) were generally stronger at longer lags. Most pollutants had more pronounced effects on children (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo><</mo><mn>18</mn></mrow></math> y old) than adults; <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></math> had strong effects on both children and the elderly (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>></mo><mn>64</mn></mrow></math> y old); and ozone had stronger effects on adults than children.

We reported positive associations between short-term air pollution exposure and increased rates of asthma ED visits. We found that air pollution exposure posed a higher risk for children and older populations. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP11661.
